reporting-org.narrative: Direction-Générale Coopération au Développement et Aide humanitaire
Directorate-general Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Aid

title.narrative: Améliorer l'accès à une éducation de qualité pour les filles et les adolescentes au Tchad
Contribution in support of people of concern to UNHCR in Afghanistan, DRC, Ethiopia, Iraq, Lebanon and Chad

description.narrative: 63,250 individuals will benefit from this project, among which 250 will directly benefit from the self-reliance and livelihoods programmes. UNHCR’s activities, as presented in this proposal, aims to reach approximately 250,000 persons (including both refugees and internally displaced persons) in the provinces of Ituri, North Kivu, South Kivu and Tanganyika provinces and the Kasai region. At the start of 2019, Ethiopia was hosting 901,235 registered refugees in the 26 camps and urban areas and settings in Ethiopia. The majority of refugees originate from South Sudan (46.6%) followed by Somalia (28.4%), Eritrea (19.2%), Sudan (4.9%), Yemen (0.2%) and other nationalities (0.7%). Out of the total refugee population, 56% are children, and 78% are women and children. The Belgium government support will contribute to protection and lifesaving assistance of the total refugee population. The contribution of the Government of Belgium will go towards providing MPCA to 120,000 vulnerable IDP families (approximately 720,000 individuals) across Iraq. The contribution of the Government of Belgium will go towards providing a monthly MPCA of USD 175 per family to up to 33,000 of the most vulnerable Syrian refugee families (220,000 individuals) to assist them in meeting their most urgent needs. The amount of cash assistance provided is calculated based on a Minimum Expenditure Basket (MEB). MPCA recipients will include female-headed households, persons with serious medical conditions, the disabled, women at risk, persons with specific legal or physical protection needs, children at risk, single parents, older persons at risk, unaccompanied/separated children and minor-headed households. This project will benefit approximately 110,218 pupils from 3 to 18 years attending the schools where UNHCR operates in Chad, 95,189 of which are refugees and 47,719 of which are refugee girls. It will also benefit 1,826 teachers, educators and education staff, of which 605 are women.

R1. Vocational training / technical skills provided R2. Warehousing provided and maintained; timely delivery of Core-relief items (CRIs) undertaken and project management services provided R3. Situation of persons of concern to UNHCR monitored The project aims to support self-reliance and livelihoods through a whole of community approach in Afghanistan. 1. Self-reliance and livelihoods improved 2. Logistics and supply optimised to serve operational needs 3. Protection from effects of armed conflict strengthened R1. Situation of PoC monitored R2. Cash grants or vouchers (multipurpose) provided R3. Cash grants or vouchers (multipurpose)provided R4. Community self-management supported R5. Community sensitization campaigns implemented - Community peace education projects implemented - Projects benefiting local and displaced communities implemented R6. The rights of person of concerns with respect to land, housing, property and documents are maintained - Capacity development supported R7. Capacity development supported for protection actors - Co-ordination mechanisms established in regards to protection related activities R8. Purchasing and timely procurement of supplies - Maintenance of vehicle fleet in adequate condition The project will support interventions in the area of protection, peaceful coexistence, reintegration and access to basic and domestic items for IDPs and refugees in Ituri, North Kivu, South Kivu and Tanganyika provinces and the Kasai region. 1. Protection from effects of armed conflict strengthened 2. Services for persons with specific needs strengthened 3. Population has sufficient basic and domestic items 4. Community mobilization strengthened and expanded 5. Peaceful coexistence with local communities promoted (IDPs and refugees) 6. Reintegration made more sustainable 7. Coordination and partnerships strengthened 8. Logistics and supply optimized to serve operational needs
R1. Increased # of health facilities equipped/constructed/rehabilitated R2. Increased # of women receiving post-test counselling and testing in PMTCT R3. Increased percentage of persons of concern with disabilities who receive services for their specific needs The projects aims to contribute towards the provision of essential services for refugees in Ethiopia. 1. Population has improved health status amongst Sudanese Refugees inWestern Ethiopia 2. Population has optimal access to reproductive health and HIV services amongst Somali Refugees 3. Services for persons with specific needs strengthened for south Sudanese refugees R1. Multi-month multipurpose cash assistance provided This project aims at supporting vulnerable displaced families in Iraq through the provision of multipurpose cash assistance. 1. Population has sufficient basic and domestic items R1. Cash grants or vouchers (multipurpose) provided The objective of the project is to help refugees in Lebanon meet their needs through multipurpose cash Assistance. The MPCA is an integral part of UNHCR’s comprehensive protection response to refugees in Lebanon. The overall goal of MPCA is to improve the living conditions of vulnerable refugee families and reduce their susceptibility to exploitation and other protection risks such as child labour and survival sex. 1. Population has sufficient basic and domestic items  Reduced gap in access to education during conflict and crisis, for refugees and the internally displaced, both inside and outside camps;  Increased access to safe and quality education that promotes gender equality;  Barriers to gender equality and to quality primary and secondary education removed. The project aims at providing a safe school environment for girls and young women, facilitating early access to education and improving retention through the system. Population has optimal access to education
